D. SHORTENING OF OTHER LONG ENDINGS.

We have hitherto always observed that final syllables in which the vowel was long by nature were not short- ened by the sole influence of the accent, unless the words to which they belonged were originally iambs¹. We have yet to mention that the same shorteniug process affected even such endings as would seem to oppose the strongest resistance to every attempt to shorten them: ds 63 es {3 ‘1283 nay, sometimes not only the vowels of these endings are shortened, but even the final consonante dropped.
